summary: This is a 2019 court opinion and order from the Southern District of Florida regarding motions in the civil case of Jane Doe 1 and Jane Doe 2 vs. the United States. It details the factual background of the Jeffrey Epstein investigation, the secret negotiation of the 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA), and the government's alleged violations of the Crime Victims' Rights Act by failing to consult with victims. This document is part of a court filing (likely a motion for summary judgment or related pleading) detailing the timeline and disputes surrounding the implementation of Jeffrey Epstein's Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA). It focuses on the government's alleged failure to properly notify victims of the NPA's terms and the defense's efforts to limit victim notification, in potential violation of the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA). This is a court order (Document 435) from the case 9:08-cv-80736-KAM, entered on February 21, 2019. The order grants partial summary judgment to Jane Doe 1 and Jane Doe 2, finding that the U.S. Government violated their rights under the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) by failing to confer with them before entering into a Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) with Jeffrey Epstein. The court rejects the Government's arguments and denies its cross-motion for summary judgment.

events.title: Initial Police Complaint

events.title: FBI Investigation Opened
events.description: At the request of Palm Beach Police, the FBI opened an investigation into allegations that Epstein and his assistants used interstate commerce to induce minors into illegal sexual activities.

events.title: Secret NPA Negotiations
events.description: Discussions took place between the U.S. Attorney's Office and Jeffrey Epstein's attorneys, culminating in the secret Non-Prosecution Agreement signed on September 24, 2007.

events.description: Jane Doe 1 provided information about her abuse and Jane Doe 2's abuse to the FBI.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement Signed
events.description: Epstein and the U.S. Attorney's Office formally entered into a Non-Prosecution Agreement, deferring federal prosecution in favor of state prosecution. The agreement was kept secret from victims.

events.description: Lefkowitz sent a letter to U.S. Attorney Acosta objecting to the proposed victim notification letter, arguing it was inappropriate before Epstein's plea or sentencing.

events.title: Starr objects to victim notification
events.description: Defense attorney Kenneth Starr sent a letter to Acosta objecting to the victim notification letter and requesting the right to review it.

events.title: FBI sends misleading notification letters

events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pled guilty to state law solicitation of prostitution charges, as part of the NPA resolution. Victims were not properly notified beforehand.

events.description: Jane Doe 1 filed an emergency petition for enforcement of her rights under the Crime Victims' Rights Act.

events.title: Victims' attorney first learns of NPA

events.title: Government sends letters to victims
events.description: The U.S. Government sent letters to victims (including Jane Doe 1 and 2) counseling patience while the investigation proceeded, despite having already bound itself to the NPA with Epstein.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office drafted an 82-page prosecution memo and 53-page indictment against Epstein for federal sexual offenses in May 2007, but never filed them.
The 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement granted immunity from federal prosecution not only to Epstein but also to any 'potential co-conspirators'.
The government deliberately kept the NPA negotiations and the final agreement secret from the identified victims, violating standard practice and the Crime Victims' Rights Act.
Epstein's attorney, Jay Lefkowitz, specifically requested and received assurances from prosecutors that they would not contact victims to inform them of the NPA.

The document reveals extensive, inappropriate collaboration between prosecutors and Epstein's defense team, including discussions on how to minimize press coverage and obscure legal jurisdiction from a judge.

The U.S. Attorney's Office and Epstein's defense team engaged in extensive correspondence and disputes over notifying the 34 identified victims about the Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) and Epstein's state plea.
FBI agents only spoke to three victims about the 'general terms' of the NPA before Epstein's defense team complained, after which victim notifications were delayed or contained limited information.

Victims, including Jane Doe 1, received letters from the FBI in early 2008 stating the case was 'under investigation,' creating the false impression that the federal investigation was ongoing despite the already-signed NPA.

Epstein's defense attorneys, including Lefkowitz, Starr, and Sanchez, repeatedly objected to victim notification letters and sought to limit the information disclosed to victims about the NPA's terms.

Victims' attorney Bradley Edwards was not informed of the NPA's existence until July 9, 2008, after Epstein had already pleaded guilty in state court, despite earlier communications where he was led to believe federal charges could still be filed.

The court found the U.S. Government violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) by entering into a Non-Prosecution Agreement with Jeffrey Epstein without conferring with or notifying the victims (Jane Doe 1 and Jane Doe 2).
The Government misled victims by sending letters asking for patience in the investigation after it had already bound itself not to prosecute Epstein via the NPA.

The court rejected the Government's argument that Jane Doe 2 was not a protected victim under the CVRA because she had made early statements favorable to Epstein, stating her status as a victim of his abuse was undisputed.
The violation of the CVRA occurred when the Government failed to advise victims of its intention to enter the NPA, preventing them from providing input before the agreement became final.
The court deferred ruling on the Government's equitable estoppel arguments and the appropriate remedy for the CVRA violation, ordering the parties to confer on how to proceed.
